title: Defense, Knights win championship
text:
Northeastern's Cole Retter sneaks through Lincoln's defense for the first touchdown of a football game Friday, Oct. 9, 2015 in Cambridge City. (Photo: Palladium-Item Joshua Smith, Palladium-Item Joshua Smith) 115 CONNECT 7 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CAMBRIDGE CITY, Ind. – It is often said that defense wins championships. 
During the first two Tri-Eastern Conference championship seasons for Northeastern, the Knights definitely had defense, but it may have been overshadowed by the overpowering offense that put up video game numbers. 
Friday night, there was no doubt; the first of three interceptions by Northeastern's Alec Hughes allowed the Knights to score on the first drive of the game, and the Knights never looked back, rolling to their 16th straight conference victory, 38-0 over the Golden Eagles. 
Northeastern moves to 6-2 on the year and 6-0 in the TEC with a game to play at home next week opposite Union City. 
"It feels great," said Hughes, who finished with three interceptions and a pair of touchdowns. "My freshman year, we won (TEC) for the first time and I wasn't a part of it, I was JV, and coming out here my sophomore year, winning it a second year felt great, this year feels even better, because I'm even bigger part of the team now. It feels great." 
Hughes' first pick gave the Knights excellent field position, and Cole Retter punched the ball in from a yard out to put the Knights on the board. Connor Bray ran the 2-point conversion to make it 8-0, but the score remained the same for the majority of the first half. 
Until Hughes struck again, snagging a punt from about midfield and returning it for a score with less than a minute remaining in the half. Bray ran for 2 again, and the Knights held a 16-0 halftime lead. 
"Truthfully, in the first half, I thought we played pretty well defensively, for the most part," Lincoln coach Phil Renforth said. "… (W)e played most of the whole second quarter 0-0 with them, until the punt return, … I'm just disappointed that we gave up so many points in the second half because I thought overall, our defense played pretty well." 
The first play from scrimmage in the second half was a 55-yard touchdown from Hughes, and Jacob Auger later ran in from 5 yards out, along with a 2-point conversion from Retter made it 30-0. 
Freshman Tanner Wilson took over at quarterback in the final quarter and scampered in from 14 yards out while Griffin Bry scored the final two-point conversion for the final score. 
The Knights won their first TEC title in 2013, going 6-1 and sharing it with Winchester. 
The Falcons are the last team mathematically alive to share the TEC title, but the Falcons need help from Randolph County rival Union City, which visits the Knights next Friday while Winchester plays at Centerville. 
"I'll be honest with you, it's been great to clinch tonight, but this team doesn't want to stop there," Northeastern coach Mike Roeder said. "I think that next week is the game they want to win and they don't want to share it." 
Hughes had three interceptions and Auger had one while Dakota Green blocked a punt and Gunnar Adams recovered. Harrison Rice and Bray each had a hand in a quarterback sack as the Knights completed their first shutout of the season since last October. 
"We just do our jobs, and when we do our jobs, things go all right," Green said. 
KNIGHTS 38, 
Northeastern 8 8 14 8 -- 38 
Lincoln 0 0 0 0 -- 0

NE- Retter, Cole 1 run, 7:05 (Bray, Connor run)
